snippet: People with mental illness account for a very small share of homicides in the United States, and keeping guns out of their hands will hardly affect rates of violence.
abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman essay argues that strident calls to keep firearms out of the hands of the mentally ill in the wake of the Newtown, Conn, shootings are misguided; cites epidemiological evidence that vast majority of people with psychiatric disorders do not commit violent acts, and that most homicides are carried out by outwardly normal people within the grip of ordinary human aggression to whom nation's laws provide nearly unfettered access to deadly force.
lead_paragraph: People with mental illness account for a very small share of homicides in the United States, and keeping guns out of their hands will hardly affect rates of violence.

headline.seo: A Misguided Focus on Mental Illness in Gun Control Debate
